Regarding your second question, to get the Servlet object from any object, you can create a ServletContext object and use the getServlet() method to get the Servlet object. Here's an example:

Suppose you have a class called "MyObject" that you want to send a message to the client using SSE. You can create a method in "MyObject" that gets the Servlet object and sends the message:
```java
public class MyObject {
    private ServletContext servletContext;
    private MensagemSSEBean mensagem;

    public void enviarMensagemSSE(MensagemSSEBean mensagem) throws IOException {
        this.mensagem = mensagem;
        servletContext.getServlet("PushServlet").enviarMensagem(mensagem);
    }
}
```
In this example, "MyObject" has a reference to the ServletContext object, which it gets using the "getServletContext()" method. Then, it calls the "enviarMensagem" method of the "PushServlet" object, passing in the "mensagem" object.

Regarding the ideal approach for this kind of problem, using a dedicated SSE servlet is a common and recommended approach. This way, you can separate the SSE logic from your other code, making it easier to maintain and scale. However, if you need to send SSE messages from different parts of your application, using a dedicated SSE servlet may not be the best approach. In that case, you could consider using a message broker like Apache Kafka or RabbitMQ to send messages between different parts of your application.
